utterance: Where are the strangers?
speaker: Atahuallpa

utterance: I will be no man's tributary! I am greater than any prince upon earth. Your emperor may be a great prince; I do not doubt it when I see that he has sent his subjects so far across the waters, and I am willing to hold him as a brother. As for the Pope of whom you speak, he must be crazy to talk of giving away countries which do not be long to him. For my faith, I will not change it. Your own God, as you say, was put to death by the very men whom he created; but mine, my God still lives in the heavens and looks down on his children.
speaker: Atahuallpa

utterance: Tell your comrades that they shall give me an account of their doings in my land. I will not go from here till they have made me full satisfaction for all the wrongs they have committed.
speaker: Atahuallpa

utterance: Do you not see that, while we stand here wasting our breath in talking with this dog, full of pride as he is, the fields are filling with Indians? Set on at once! I absolve you.
speaker: Fray Vicente de Valverde

utterance: Let no one who values his life strike at the Inca
speaker: Francisco Pizarro

utterance: Headquarters, St. Engracia. Capitulation.
speaker: General Lefebvre

utterance: Headquarters, Zaragoza. War to the knife.
speaker: Don José Palafox

utterance: Messire, I am but a poor maiden; I know not how to ride to the wars or to lead menat-arms.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: I must go to the king, even if I wear my limbs to the very knees.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: I had far rather rest and spin by my mother's side, for this is no work of my choosing; but I must go and do it, for my Lord wills it.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: And who is your Lord?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: He is God.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: Gentle Dauphin, my name is Jeanne the Maid. The heavenly King sends me to tell you that you shall be anointed and crowned in the town of Rheims, and you shall be lieutenant of the heavenly King, who is the King of France.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: Sire Dieu, I pray you to do for La Hire what La Hire would do for you were you captain-at-arms and he God
speaker: La Hire

utterance: Touch them yourself, your touch will be just as good as mine.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: The Maid prays and requires you, to work no more distraction in France, but to come in her company to rescue the Holy Sepulchre from the Turk.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: I bring you the best aid ever sent to any one, the aid of the King of heaven.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: You have taken your counsel, and I take mine.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: Wait a while, eat and drink. So soon as my standard touches the wall you shall enter the fort.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: O gentle King, the pleasure of God is done.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: Would it were his pleasure that I might go and keep sheep once more with my sisters and my brothers; they would be so glad to see me again.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: Do you believe that you are in a state of peace?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: If I am not, God will put me in it. If I am, God will keep me in it.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: Since it has pleased God that I should be taken, it is for the best.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: Will you submit to the judgment of the Church Militant?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I have come to the King of France by commission from God and from the Church Triumphant above. To that church I submit. I had far rather die than renounce what I have done by my Lord's command.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: Our Lord can make me hear it without your aid.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: Do your voices forbid you to submit to the Church and Pope?
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Ah, no! Our Lord first served.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: I hold to my Judge, to the King of heaven and earth. God has always been my Lord in all that I have done. The devil has never had power over me.
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: Oh, Rouen, Rouen, I have great fear lest you suffer for my death. Yes, my voices were of God! They have never deceived me!
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: Jesus!
speaker: JEANNE D'ARC

utterance: We are lost, we have burned a saint.
speaker: an English soldier

utterance: "By the waters of Babylon we sat down and wept,"
speaker: Vincent de Paul

utterance: "I have them!"
speaker: Napoleon

utterance: "The foe! They come! they come!"
speaker: citizens

utterance: "We drink the downfall Of an accursed land!"
speaker: the elder of the village

utterance: "Go forth, save Bregenz, And then, if need be, die!"
speaker: Tyrol maid

utterance: "Faster!"
speaker: Tyrol maid

utterance: "O God! help Bregenz, And bring me there in time!"
speaker: Tyrol maid

utterance: "Nine," "ten," "eleven,"
speaker: warder

utterance: "In a few days the town of Ghent shall be the most honored or the most humbled town in Christendom."
speaker: Peter van den Bossche

utterance: "Then we will fight."
speaker: PHILIP VAN ARTEVELDE

utterance: "If you lose the battle you need not return to Ghent, for you will find your families dead in their homes."
speaker: old men, the women, and the children

utterance: "Ghent Ghent!"
speaker: the Ghent people

utterance: "Of all things, I do not love writing."
speaker: Marlborough

utterance: "I have great reason to hope that everything will go well, for I have the pleasure to find all the officers willing to obey without knowing any other reason than that it is my desire, which is very different from what it was in Flanders, where I was obliged to have the consent of a council of war for everything I undertook."
speaker: Marlborough

utterance: "'Tis some poor fellow's skull," said he, “Who fell in that great victory.
speaker: Old Kaspar

utterance: "For many thousand men," said he, "Were slain in that great victory."
speaker: Old Kaspar

utterance: "Now tell us what 'twas all about," Young Peterkin he cries; And little Wilhelmine looks up With wonder-waiting eyes— "Now tell us all about the war, And what they fought each other for."
speaker: Peterkin

utterance: "It was the English," Kaspar cried, "Who put the French to rout; But what they fought each other for I could not well make out; But everybody said," quoth he, "That 'twas a famous victory."
speaker: Old Kaspar

utterance: "Why, 'twas a very wicked thing!"
speaker: Wilhelmine

utterance: "Nay, nay, my little girl!" quoth he, "It was a famous victory.
speaker: Old Kaspar

utterance: "But what good came of it at last?"
speaker: Peterkin

utterance: "Why, that I can not tell," said he ; "But 'twas a famous victory."
speaker: Old Kaspar

utterance: "How are ye, man?" cried King James, speaking in a Scotch accent; "By my crown, Sir Oliver, but I am glad to see ye!"
speaker: King James I

utterance: "I have brought my son Charlie to see ye," said the king; "I hope, Sir Oliver, ye have a son of your own to be his playmate."
speaker: King James I

utterance: "What a noble little prince he is!" exclaimed Sir Oliver, lifting his hands in admiration, "No, please your Majesty, I have no son to be the playmate of his Royal Highness; but there is a nephew of mine somewhere about the house. He is near the prince's age, and will be but too happy to wait upon his royal highness.'"
speaker: Sir Oliver Cromwell

utterance: "Send for him, man! send for him!" said the king.
speaker: King James I

utterance: "Here, please your Majesty, is my nephew," said Sir Oliver, somewhat ashamed of Noll's appearance and demeanor.-" Oliver, make your obeisance to the king's majesty."
speaker: Sir Oliver Cromwell

utterance: "Nephew," said Sir Oliver, "pay your duty to the prince."
speaker: Sir Oliver Cromwell

utterance: "I owe him no duty," cried Noll, thrusting aside the prince's hand with a rude laugh. "Why should I kiss that boy's hand?"
speaker: Oliver Cromwell

utterance: "Thou art a bold boy," said he, looking fixedly at little Noll; "and if thou live to be a man, my son Charlie would do wisely to be friends with thee."
speaker: King James I

utterance: "I never will!" cried the little prince, stamping his foot.
speaker: Prince Charles

utterance: "Peace, Charlie, peace!" said the king; then addressing Sir Oliver and the attendants: "Harm not the urchin; for he has taught my son a good lesson, if Heaven do but give him grace to profit by it. Hereafter, should he be tempted to tyrannize over the stubborn race of Englishmen, let him remember little Noll Cromwell and his own bloody nose."
speaker: King James I
addressee: Sir Oliver Cromwell and the attendants

utterance: "You little villain !" cried his uncle, "what have you been about? Down on your knees this instant, and ask the prince's pardon! How dare you lay your hand on the king's majesty's royal son?"
speaker: Sir Oliver Cromwell

utterance: "He struck me first," grumbled the valiant little Noll; "and I have only given him his due."
speaker: Oliver Cromwell

utterance: "No!" said he, sternly; "better that one man should perish than that the whole country should be ruined for his sake. It is resolved that he shall die!"
speaker: Oliver Cromwell

utterance: "Why was it?" said Cromwell to himself, or might have said, as he gazed at the pale features in the coffin-"why was it that this great king fell, and that poor Noll Cromwell has gained all the power of the realm?"
speaker: Oliver Cromwell

utterance: This is wonderful in a youth like you
speaker: Lorenzo de' Medici

utterance: But, there is one thing I do not quite approve, though it is but a slight fault in so good a work-you have restored all the old man's teeth; whereas, you know, a person of that age has generally some wanting.
speaker: Lorenzo de' Medici

utterance: Do you know to whom you speak?
speaker: Michael Angelo Buonarotti

utterance: Perfectly well, and I only do my duty in obeying the orders my master has given.
speaker: A groom of the chamber

utterance: Then tell the Pope, if he wants me, he may come and seek me elsewhere himself.
speaker: Michael Angelo Buonarotti

utterance: I have been expelled from the antechamber of your Holiness without meriting disgrace; therefore I have left Rome to preserve my reputation. I will not return, as your Holiness commands. If I have been deemed worthless one day, how can I be valued the next, except by a caprice alike discreditable to the one who shows it, and the one toward whom it is shown?
speaker: Michael Angelo Buonarotti

utterance: We know the humor of men like Michael Angelo. If he will return, we promise that none shall offend him or interfere with him, and he shall be reinstated in our apostolic grace.
speaker: Pope Julius II

utterance: You have treated the Pope as the King of France himself would not have dared. We can not bring him to war against the state on your account; therefore you must obey his will.
speaker: The chief magistrate of Florence

utterance: Instead of your coming to us, you seem to have expected that we should wait upon you.
speaker: Pope Julius II

utterance: One must needs make allowance for such men, who are ignorant of everything except their art.
speaker: A prelate

utterance: Foolish man, it is thou who hast vilified Michael Angelo; I have not. He is a man of genius, and thou art an ignorant fellow. Depart from my sight this moment!
speaker: Pope Julius II

utterance: I have painted, men who were poor, nor wished for riches-holy men, to whom gold was an object of contempt. I will add nothing.
speaker: Michael Angelo Buonarotti

utterance: Three more windows will be placed there
speaker: Michael Angelo Buonarotti

utterance: You never told us of that before
speaker: A cardinal

utterance: Nor will I be accountable to you for declaring all that I do, or intend to do! It is yours to provide money, and keep off thieves: to build St. Peter's is mine!
speaker: Michael Angelo Buonarotti

utterance: I go yet to school, that I may continue to learn.
speaker: Michael Angelo Buonarotti

utterance: He'll make a capital workman one of these days. No fear but that Isaac will do well in the world, and be a rich man before he dies.
speaker: Isaac Newton's grandmother

utterance: But, Isaac, you have forgotten one thing that belongs to a mill.
speaker: One of Isaac Newton's playmates

utterance: What is that?
speaker: Isaac Newton

utterance: Why, where is the miller?
speaker: One of Isaac Newton's playmates

utterance: That is true-I must look out for one
speaker: Isaac Newton

utterance: "O Diamond, Diamond, thou little knowest the mischief thou hast done!"
speaker: Isaac Newton

utterance: "I seem to myself like a child playing on the sea-shore, and picking up here and there a curious shell or a pretty pebble, while the boundless ocean of Truth lies undiscovered before me."
speaker: Isaac Newton

utterance: "Forasmuch as in the writing of the same, my pen is worn, my hand is weary and not steadfast, mine eyes dimmed with overmuch looking on the white paper, and my courage not so prone and ready to labor as it hath been, and that age creepeth on me daily and feebleth all the body, and also because I have promised to divers gentlemen and to my friends to address to them as hastily as I might the said book, therefore I have practised and learned at my great charge and dispense to ordain this said book in print after the manner and form as ye may see, and is not written with pen and ink as other books be, to the end that every man may have them at once, for all the books of this story here emprynted as ye see were begun in one day and also finished in one day."
speaker: William Caxton

utterance: "If it please you, any man, spiritual or temporal, to buy any pyes of two or three commemorations of Salisbury, all emprynted after the form of the present letter, which be well and truly correct, let him come to Westminster in the almonry at the red pale, and he shall have them good chepe."
speaker: William Caxton

utterance: "Now, I am a made man for life."
speaker: George Stephenson

utterance: "In the earlier period of my career, when Robert was a little boy, I saw how deficient I was in education, and I made up my mind that he should not labor under the same defect, but that I would put him to a good school, and give him a liberal training. I was, however, a poor man; and how do you think I managed? I betook myself to mending my neighbors' clocks and watches at nights, after my daily labor was done, and thus I procured the means of educating my son."
speaker: George Stephenson

utterance: "Now, lads, I will tell you that I think you will live to see the day, though I may not live so long, when railways will come to supersede almost all other methods of conveyance in this country-when mailcoaches will go by railway, and railways will become the great highway for the king and all his subjects. The time is coming when it will be cheaper for a workingman to travel on a railway than to walk on foot. I know there are great and almost insurmountable difficulties that will have to be encountered; but what I have said will come to pass as sure as we live. I only wish I only wish I may live to see the day, though that I can scarcely hope for, as I know how slow all human progress is, and with what difficulty I have been able to get the locomotive adopted, notwithstanding my more than ten years' successful experiment at Killing worth."
speaker: George Stephenson

utterance: "SAM, I am very feeble and ailing to-day. You must go to Uttoxeter in my stead, and tend the book-stall in the market-place there."
speaker: Mr. Michael Johnson

utterance: "Sir,' said he, "I will not go to Uttoxeter market!"
speaker: Sam

utterance: "Well, Sam, if for the sake of your foolish pride you can suffer your poor sick father to 185 stand all day in the noise and confusion of the market when he ought to be in his bed, I have no more to say. But you will think of this, Sam, when I am dead and gone."
speaker: Mr. Johnson

utterance: "Mother, did you think father seemed very ill to-day?"
speaker: Sam

utterance: "Yes, Sam, your father did look very ill; and it is a pity he did not send you to Uttoxeter in his stead. You are a great boy now, and would rejoice, I am sure, to do something for your poor father, who has done so much for you."
speaker: his mother

utterance: "Yes, here is the very spot!"
speaker: the old gentleman

utterance: "How could you dare to succor the enemy of my crown and kingdom?"
speaker: old King George II

utterance: "It was no more than I would have done for your Majesty, had you been in a like situation."
speaker: Flora Macdonald

utterance: "I went to London to be hanged, but rode back in a chaiseand-four with Flora Macdonald."
speaker: Malcolm McLeod

utterance: "You see, that she is a thoroughly good creature, and that under her modest exterior lies a spirit capable of the most exalted devotion-a devotion so entire, that daring is not so much a quality of her nature, as that the most perfect sympathy with suffering or endangered humanity swallows up and annihilates everything like fear or self-consideration—puts out, in fact, every sentiment but itself."
speaker: William Howitt

utterance: "When my father comes hame frae the pleugh," she said, "Oh! then please wauken me."
speaker: Jessie Brown

utterance: "The Hielanders! Oh! dinna ye Hear the slogan far awa'? The McGregors. Oh! I ken it weel; It's the grandest o' them a'!"
speaker: Jessie Brown

utterance: "God bless the bonnie Hielanders! We're saved-we're saved!"
speaker: Jessie Brown

utterance: "Oh! dinna ye hear the slogan far awa'?"
speaker: Jessie Brown

utterance: "The slogan's done, But winna ye hear it noo? The Campbells are comin'! It's no a dream; Our succors hae broken through!"
speaker: Jessie Brown

utterance: "Halloo, on deck there!"
speaker: Dr. Elisha Kent Kane

utterance: "to call all hands to lay aft, and take two reefs in the stove-pipe."
speaker: Dr. Elisha Kent Kane

utterance: "We expected you! We were sure you would come!"
speaker: four poor helpless figures

utterance: "Bonsall and Horton, two of our stoutest men, came to me, begging permission to sleep; they were not cold, the wind did not enter them now; a little sleep was all that they wanted."
speaker: Dr. Elisha Kent Kane
